Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course provided a solid foundation into electromagnetism as well as a few other topics, such as light. I also appreciated the ability to use some more interesting math in this class.
I definitely learned more about electronics and magnetics. I liked that this course didn't shy away too much from the math side of things.
I learned about electricity and magnetism. I also learned how to be inventive while solving physics-related problems.
My skills in problem solving with my math skills to explain physical concepts.

I gained a solid conceptual understanding of electricity and magnetism, including topics I had not previously seen at all. The class (particularly the exams) focused more on qualitative comprehension rather than rigorous math, which made me focus more on the conceptual details instead of just blindly solving problems.
I practiced viewing physics questions conceptually as well as physically and to connect meaning to the questions we tackle.
Basic mathematical foundations of E&M.
A basic understanding of the principles of electrostatics, electrodynamics, and quantum mechanics. It was a very thorough course that wasnt extremely hard that o highly recommend!
I was introduced to the basics of electricity and magnetism, and a little bit of quantum mechanics towards the end of the course.

Gained a bunch of physics knowledge, but also understood some of the problem solving techniques that are employed on tricky questions, and how to tackle problems that I initially have no clue how to solve.
I learned the basics of electricity and magnetism, optics, and quantum mechanics.
I deepened my knowledge in Electrodynamics, as well as managed to bridge the concepts of physics with the application of integral calculus
A great physics course covering all of Maxwell's equations, a bit of relativity, and quantum mechanics.
Electricity and magnetism as mostly a review of high school physics, with an intro to optics and quantum mechanics that was interesting if not super in depth.
Electrostatics, electrodynamics, magnetism, fields, Maxwell's equations, quantum mechanics (wave/particle duality)
Electricity and magnetism, optics, quantum
Electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics
I learned the other side of physics. Not mechanics
E&M, optics, quantum

I gained knowledge on electrostatics, DC circuits, AC circuits, capacitors, resistors, inductors, magnetism, optics, waves, and quantum mechanics. Although this sounds like a lot of material, most of it interconnects, and Sarah Demers is a great instructor for the second-half of this semester (she loves quantum mechanics). You will learn Maxwell's equations, and many different scenarios on how to use them. Creative problem-solving is a tool that you will develop over the semester, and it is imperative to learning and doing the problems.

I developed the ability to analyze complex electromagnetic systems via the use of symmetry-based approaches, fundamental laws of nature, and unique problem-solving strategies. Furthermore, I also gained an appreciation for the natural phenomena of our world.

The course covered a large percentage of modern physics, particularly Electricity and Magnetism, Geometric Optics and Quantum Mechanics. The course focused on gaining a conceptual understanding of these topics and being apply them to problems.

I gained a lot of skill in approaching problems (especially problem sets) and conceptually understanding the parts of each mathematical formula instead of just going through the math. I prefer that conceptual understanding much more to actually doing the math, but I acknowledge that sometimes doing the math is necessary to understand the concepts. 
I feel like I know more about the universe now, which is fun for its own sake.
I learned physics.

This was a terrible class. I did not gain any knowledge or insights, besides the fact that Yale Physics is lackluster and hopeless. Welcome to a class where you will be barraged by terrible problem sets, where you will be forced to use a textbook that reads like an old man rambling, where you will not be given a single practice problem, where the professor barely explains anything if she even deigns to show up, and where -- if review sessions are held at all -- the TA's are more clueless than the students. The only plausible "skill" I developed was how to collaborate on a problem set in order to not fail. This is not a class where you succeed or feel accomplishment. This is a class where you measure yourself by how lost you feel.

I feel like I learned the material, and developed a sense for how bizarre quantum mechanics are. The breadth of the course gave me surface access to the properties of several different physical phenomena.
I learned about electricity and magnetism, optics, and quantum mechanics, along with general skills for solving mathematical physics problems.

The lectures in this course were very interesting and managed to keep good pace despite the attempts by the textbook to slow down at every turn. I found the topics covered to be very interesting, although I sometimes wished that the material was a bit more challenging. The exams and even the problem sets didn't always reach the level of depth that I was expecting.

I would say that this course is composed mostly of weaknesses. The strongest part is probably the textbook which was written by the professor who used to teach this class. It seems that since that time, Physics 201 has fallen very low on the physics department's priority list. Our teacher clearly did not view our class as a priority. She missed probably over three weeks of class in all, she often came unprepared, and she often struggled to understand her own derivations. We did not get any assignments back in any sort of timely manner, despite the fact that the class had only about 60 people and had 2 TAs and a professor. I was very very disappointed in this class and learned most of the material from reading the textbook or watching Shankar's lectures online.
I really appreciate how Professor Demers was really engaged and interested in the content. I enjoyed how we derived the answers to all the problems.

The professor was smart, explained things well, and structured the class well, but clearly had not taught the class before. I believe that this class would have benefitted from making the PSets due not at midnight on a friday night because it encouraged a) letting it infringe on social lives b) rushing through the Psets to either get to bed or make it to social plans with friends.

The class was very engaging and the material was consistently a good balance of challenging and interesting. It did seem change in structure as the semester went along: the second two exams were very different in format than the first (more conceptual questions and fewer calculations), so at times it felt like the structure and expectations were a bit inconsistent.

Weakness
-took forever to hand back homework and midterms so you could not really learn from your mistakes before the final
-teacher is kind of annoying
Strenghts: Sarah was so passionate about what she was teaching  and this class made me like physics even more

Every lecture needs to be standardized with respect to Shankar's textbook. In 200, Prof. Poland did a decent job at this. In 201, Prof. Demers often veered off course and this made it difficult to keep track of the material. Additionally, the Physics department needs to pick an instructor who will be present to give us lectures 95% of the time. Prof. Demers often had to travel to her various research groups around the world in lieu of lecturing. It was not her fault that she had to travel so much, but the department should pick somebody else who is more focused on teaching to teach this courseespecially because students decide whether to major in Physics based on the 200/201 sequence.
The problem sets are great for learning and Professor Demers is great! One improvement I think that could be made is greater clarity about what we need to k ow for exams and quizzes.
I think that the course felt very disorganized. Students received their first midterm back at least a whole month after they took it.

The course was very strangely lacking in test prep materials--even when promised practice problems, we often only received material covering a fraction of what would appear on the test.  TA review sessions were, on the whole, entirely unhelpful (though Professor Urry's review sessions were fantastic, and I'd highly recommend attending), and it was at times unclear how we should proceed leading up to a midterm.

As someone who hadn't taken AP physics or any physics for probably four years I found keeping up conceptually in this class was very difficult. The book wasn't helpful at all, so if concept weren't explained in class I was totally lost. I think using a book that focuses more on a deep conceptual understanding rather than just the math derivations of equations would be helpful.
Strengths: a good overview of the topics, a clear organization
The physics office hour sessions are extremely helpful and a really good tool to get students working through problems together.
I thought this course was amazing, but could be improved by covering less material that had already been covered in AP Physics C.
Honestly a well-paced, interesting intro physics class--no complaints

The course was taught well and covered many topics in E&M and quantum. It overlapped with a lot of material I had already learned in AP physics C, but I liked the extension to quantum mechanics at the end, and I feel like I now have a better understanding of Maxwell's equations.
Study halls were great! Lectures could have been more well organized

This class is strong in that its super interesting and beautiful, and the professor is very friendly and has a good teaching style.  The textbook is also really good. The psets are also fair. Can't really think of any weaknesses.
I think there should be more practice problems and practice outside of the normal psets and exams

One strength I found was the candid and relaxed nature of the instructor, Professor Demers: she brings a calm approach to physics, which helps relieve some of the anxiety of not understanding everything. In one of her lectures, she said "one thing you need to do is stop trying to understand the material," which I think makes perfect sense in quantum mechanics. However, one weakness (for me) was her reliance on Shankar's text: she would reference things in the text and expected you to read some of the chapters from it. However, if you're like me and don't like buying the textbooks and just try and understand the material otherwise, you are in luck: it is easy to gain the understanding of material through just her lectures and the notes you write down from them. Another strength is that the PSETs help prepare you for the exam, but the PSET questions are harder than the exam questions, therefore not requiring you to imitate answers to PSET questions. I found this useful, since I knew that we wouldn't have to know everything on the PSETs, and instead it allowed me to focus on broader questions and topics within the course.

Sarah is a very enthusiastic professor and her excitement can be very motivating. She does well to focus less on vague theoretical proofs and more on practical concepts that are more useful. Unfortunately, however, the course was not structured well in enough to tap into Sarah's potential. We often skipped past some concepts or chapters, and sometimes Sarah would drift off topic and leave others under-cooked.

I had trouble with Shankar's textbook. I felt like my background in mathematics was not high enough to follow, and maybe it was not (because I'd just started taking Math 120 this semester.) Studying for the final exam, I felt much clearer on what the equations meant, because I'd gone through a semester of Math 120 preparation. In the beginning of the semester, I thought the problem sets were fine conceptually, but I found myself struggling to do even the easier questions for problems that involved surface integrals and otherwise. During Physics study hall, other people just seemed to understand how to do the problems, while I did not. Most weeks I had to rely on others' help in order to get through problem sets. In those situations, I understood concepts, but not how to solve problems.
Could be faster grading. Interesting material though. More rigorous proofs would be nice.

As a disclaimer, normally I try to find the positive in classes. Unfortunately, I just can't for this class. There were no positives. This class is miserable and useless. The material was taught poorly. The TA's didn't know what was going on. The textbook provided, rambling, lackluster explanations. There were no practice problems. Our professor was so engrossed in her research that she forgot that there were students depending on her for their education. Problem sets did not correlate to exams. Exams were easy -- if you knew what to possibly study. That was the worst part of this class; the questions on the exams were so easy, but people didn't know how to answer them. Imagine taking a class at Yale, and it being a complete waste of time where you learn nothing. That is Physics 201. How could this class be improved? Everything needs improvement, so start from square one. Get a new professor who actually is knowledgeable about the material and cares, get TA's who know how to teach and explain things to students, get a new textbook that has practice problems and clear explanations, rewrite problem sets to better fit the material, provide practice exams and practice problems to students, provide review sessions to students, and rewrite exams that better fit the material included on problem sets. This class was ridiculously bad. It was an embarrassment to Yale.
Not very in depth, but good breadth.

I likes the breadth of the course. I feel like it gave a nice introduction to a wide variety of branches of physics, and I felt more or less introduced to the material. I think I would've liked to see a little bit more mathematical rigor in the psets, and a little more consistency in the frequency of them. There were some weeks were we missed them, and while my other STEM classes reached pset 11 or 12, we only got to 9 in physics.

The course does a very good job presenting the foundation for each concept and providing homework problems that extend the topics taught in lecture. Study halls are a great chance to work with others on difficult problems and solidify understanding. I would have liked more practice problems to be available before each exam because problem solving practice is such an important part of this course.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, particularly one with a little bit of a background in E&M. The overall course is actually a bit less difficult than 200, and I personally think that the material is more interesting, so there's that to look forward to.

I don't know if I would recommend this course. However, I have heard bad things about all of the intro physics sequence, so if you need to take physics, there's pretty much no great option. This class definitely has the potential to be good if the teacher cares at all about teaching it. In our case, this was sadly not what happened. The content of this class is obviously important and sort of essential if you want to do anything related to physics, but the structure (or lack thereof) and the teaching of this course really prevent me from recommending it.
Yes. I greatly enjoyed the lectures and the content is fascinating.
I'd recommend it to those looking for a challenging and therefore interesting intro course.
Yes, I would. It provides a good fundamental introduction to many areas of physics and is challenging but fun.
Really No but its a pre req so i guess but this is the first time its been taught in lectures so it was her first time teaching it but i felt it was very disorganised
YES!!!!!! The level of the material is not very hard, and Sarah makes everything so interesting.

If you are thinking about majoring in Physics, shop both 200/201 sequence and the 260/261 sequence. If you think you might be able to handle the 260 stuff, just take that course. 200/201 is just not that great. Some of the material at the end of the course is very exciting, but the bulk of the semester will be on material that is not. I recommend 260 for students interested in Physics and do not take 200 at all if you just need it for MB&B or pre-med. Take 180 instead.
Yes, for anyone who wants a basic understanding of E and M its a good course
Sure, it is a nice way to learn about what quantum mechanics is.

Yes, only because there's not really a way around it for a physics major.  It wasn't the worst course ever, but definitely had more than its fair share of problems, and was an at times frustrating experience.

If you are a physics major or very comfortable in physics I would take this class. If you are unfamiliar with physics, regardless of your math background, I would take 180 or 181. I think they move a little slower.
Absolutely would recommend to any student interested in majoring in physics
Yes

Yes, physics is a good amount of time / work, but it is very manageable if you go to the office hours sessions. 201 seems like a similar amount of work to 200 but is more conceptual, so if that's what you're looking for I'd take 200/201.
Yes, Sarah is an amazing lecturer and really knows her stuff, and the content is easy to understand.
Yes, the concepts are interesting and the PSETs aren't very hard, especially if you do them in study hall. Support for this class is super easy to find between study halls and office hours.

It's a good intro E&M class. The material overlaps a lot with AP Physics C, but the quantum mechanics at the end is nice. Sarah is a very good professor and she really cares about the class. The psets aren't too bad, but going to the study halls is sometimes essential.
If they're interested in physics, yes

Take this class! Sarah Demers is an amazing professor, so take it with her if you get a chance. Some students felt that her lecturing style was unorganized, but I didn't feel this way at all. I relied on the textbook less than I did in PHYS 200.
If you need to take it, take it
Yes

I would definitely recommend this class to another student if that student wanted a more comprehensive introduction to physics, especially if that student is considering being a physics major: you will probably cover all the material in PHYS 200/201 sequence that will be gone over again in the physics major track. This means you will already have an understanding of the concepts before they are taught to you. I also found this class easier when I took CHEM 163, where we learn about quantum mechanics in the first third of fall semester (and take PHYS 201 spring). This is a very interesting class, and it would benefit the most curious students.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The course was marvelously taught, with all of the concepts well-explained and questions answered. In addition, the subject-matter of the course was fascinating from a conceptual and mathematical point of view, making it an amazing experience for students interested in learning about electricity, magnetism, and how their intertwined nature defines our world.

I would, but only if you do not mind the slightly unstructured nature of the course, and are willing to learn extensively on your own to cover the material. Sarah is a great person to enthuse you and to have interesting, unfettered conversation, but don't go into this if you expect lectures to be exhaustive.
This course is significantly more work than phys 181.  I see no real benefit from taking this class in favor of 181.

I would say yes. I think it is more stimulating and conceptually more challenging than Physics 181, but it is still manageable. I think you do learn more and get a better physical understanding than just plugging numbers into equations. The students who are likely to take this class are more likely to be engineers than pre-med, so I think you learn more from your peers in this class as well.
If you like physics sure.

No! One thousand times no! This was the most useless, hopeless, regressive class that I have ever taken at Yale. If a kid needs to take Physics, take Physics 180/181, or 170/171. Do not waste your time on Physics 200/201. You will be left miserable, angry, and struggling through a class that does its utmost to make you suffer. Nothing about this class was organized in a logical, coherent manner. If I knew before coming to Yale that I would be taking classes like this, I would not have come to Yale. There is no reason for Physics 201 to exist as a class. Combine the worst facets of every lecture course that you have taken, add a sprinkle of an uninvested professor, difficult problem sets, limited study resources, no practice problems, obscure problem sets, a terrible textbook, no review sessions, exam material that does not correlate to the problem sets, and voila you have Physics 201. This class is an embarrassment to  Yale and a disgrace to the student body who worked so hard to succeed with all the odds against them. I am disappointed in Yale for this low-quality excuse for a course. I am in awe and amazement that I actually payed for this. Anyone considering this class, re-evaluate your life choices. Stay away.
Of intro physics courses, I hear the psets are less computational than 181, but 261 might be more interesting.

If they were interested in physics, yes. Its a decent course, and provides access to upper-lever courses. If they weren't interested in physics, no. I don't feel that the course is stimulating enough to hold the attention of someone if they aren't sold on the material.

Yes. From the perspective of an engineering major, this course's topics seem like a somewhat odd mix, and optics and quantum mechanics don't seem to add much practical value. However, these extra topics help show a variety of problem-solving techniques, and the course overall does a very good job teaching mathematical problem-solving skills.
